Issues.Title: Visual Studio - Remove compilation errors in .g.cs files
Issues.Body: When a component fails to compile, the error list shows the {componentname}.g.cs files, which are not clickable in VS. Is it possible to hide these files?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Visual Studio - Remove compilation errors in .g.cs files " (#1580)

Issues.Title: Remove useless call to StateHasChanged
Issues.Body:
This removes an unecessary call to StateHasChanged if task is not finished when we reach the "if" line 172

or we could remove StateHasChanged from ContinueAfterLifecycleTask as it's already called line 178 and 212
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Remove useless call to StateHasChanged" (#1579)

Issues.Title: escape quotes in event handler attribute content
Issues.Body:
Fix broken codegen due to double quotes not escaped inside single quoted event handlers.
fixes #1527
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "escape quotes in event handler attribute content" (#1577)

Issues.Title: erroneous BL9986 - "Component attributes do not support complex content", but it isn't a component attribute
Issues.Body:
This bug is basically #784 resurrected because it's still happening to me - I can't use razor templating inside an attribute of a builtin html element, as in `<button class="foo @bar">`.

Reproducing it was kind of weird - putting the same component in an empty project *doesn't* produce the error, so I had to take an existing solution and minimise it. I'm not sure what subtle difference remains between the two.

Here's the repro: https://github.com/gulbanana/bl9986. Just clone and `dotnet build`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "erroneous BL9986 - "Component attributes do not support complex content", but it isn't a component attribute" (#1578)

Issues.Title: Many developers seem to be lacking empathy and worse...
Issues.Body:
As far as I understand, Server Side Blazor relates to Razor Components, right ? 
So, why in the world so many developers, here in github and elsewhere, use the phrase sever-side Blazor to mean something different than Razor Components; that is, they actually relate to the ASP.NET Core hosted Blazor. When I read stuff, I often find myself confused of their confusion, wasting so much energy just to understand what they are trying to convey. Often I find it hard to decipher and follow their intention just because they are negligent, perhaps even willfully negligent.

What can be done about this ? This is serious and can lead to much confusion and 'disasters' . I hope you guy won't dismiss this post as a mere fastidious nagging. Developers should be concise and use the phrase "Razor Components" to refer to Blazor application running on the server.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Many developers seem to be lacking empathy and worse..." (#1569)

Issues.Title: problem with event on input - blazor binding event to global (Blazor 0.6.0)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "problem with event on input - blazor binding event to global (Blazor 0.6.0)" (#1575)

Issues.Title: async BlazorComponent Lifecycle methods return null
Issues.Body:
The async lifecycle events return null instead of a completed task. This means that when you override one of those methods and Visual Studio automatically adds a `base.OnInitAsync()` you get a null reference exception, but without any real hint about where it's coming from (I only figured it out with help from someone on gitter).

The answer in this case is to not call `base.OnInitAsync()` because the method is defined as
```
protected virtual Task OnInitAsync()
    => null
```

I think it would be better to return a completed task
```
protected virtual Task OnInitAsync()
    => Task.CompletedTask;
```

And I would be willing to sift through the solution looking for places where we're returning null and should be returning a completed Task, but don't want to submit a PR if there is some reason I don't understand that returning null there makes more sense despite the confusion it caused me.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "async BlazorComponent Lifecycle methods return null" (#1576)

Issues.Title: How To Mix Mvc Pages With Blazor
Issues.Body:
i mean i will Create Web App Mvc How use Into This App Blazor
,,
And Check Input Validation In Blazor 
Like Model Pages and Models In Mvc.

Any One Have Way to Mix mvc-With Blazor In save app
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How To Mix Mvc Pages With Blazor " (#1568)

Issues.Title: When tracing dependencies *without* linking, don't fail the build if there are unresolved dependencies
Issues.Body:
There are legitimate use cases for referencing BCL assemblies that *aren't* in the Mono WebAssembly BCL, particularly for Blazor-on-the-server which runs on CoreCLR (and hence supports a broader BCL) anyway.

Developers can already do this themselves if they are using the linker (by passing `--skip-unresolved true` to the linker). But before this PR there was no way to get around the problem if you're not using the linker, which you typically aren't for server-side Blazor.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "When tracing dependencies *without* linking, don't fail the build if there are unresolved dependencies" (#1574)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Blazor Server side, child component not always updates view" (#1573)

Issues.Title: SVG not rendering properly with Blazor
Issues.Body:
_Originally posted by @mdegroot71 in https://github.com/aspnet/Blazor/issue_comments#issuecomment-430270522_

I am having the same issues.  I've taken all of the same CSS, Javascript and produced HTML from Blazor, popped it into a static HTML page and ran it.  The SVG scales as it should without any workarounds.  I'm using Chrome.  When I run it with Blazor, the SVG behaves in a weird way.  This isn't a CSS issue.  This is definitely a rendering issue b/c no matter how I inject the SVG, it still does not behave as if Blazor was not present.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "SVG not rendering properly with Blazor" (#1571)

Issues.Title: Define routeable components in a library
Issues.Body:
So I'm not even sure if this is supposed to work, but I was expecting it would. I have created a new Blazor application hosted in an ASP.NET Core application. I then added a Blazor library project to my solution and added a reference to that library from the Client project. Now I've defined a component with an @page attribute and was expecting to be able to route to that component, but that does not seem to work.

I can see that the library is being loaded over the network, but when I try to navigate to the route of the component I get an error in the console stating that no component could be found at that route. So I'm guessing it's not finding the component with the @page attribute. Is this by design?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Define routeable components in a library" (#1570)

Issues.Title: Authentication for serverside blazor
Issues.Body:
I've read this: https://github.com/aspnet/Blazor/issues/1449
and this: https://github.com/aspnet/Blazor/issues/698

And still have some questions. 
The last option (of 1449) kind of defeats the purpose of SS blazor in my opinion. This way you are losing lots of the benefits. (creating a API surface and client), but that will work.

And the first option can only be used to control access to the whole application, right? Not to identify users in the components code.

For instance, I would like to be able to use:

`Thread.CurrentPrincipal` 

in my components, but enabling authentication(in the server part) does not provide this (always null). I kind of understand why.. the SignalR stuff bypasses everything of the default stack, and provides no auth bearer or something, I guess?

In my opinion being able to use a principal in serverside blazor essential for enterprise applications.
Am I missing something? Or is this not possible yet? And is my scenario covered by 698?

Thanks
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Authentication for serverside blazor" (#1554)

Issues.Title: Request: Configurable folders to serve the client from
Issues.Body:
Right now in Blazor, unless you specify "_framework", the server is going to try to send you index.html - if the URL is "bad".

(See: 
https://github.com/aspnet/Blazor/blob/master/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server/Builder/BlazorApplicationBuilderExtensions.cs#L162)

It would be useful to be able to configure the URLs from which the framework will be serviced.  ie - If I specify a bad URL, I would rather my server send a 404 than deliver a couple of megabytes of framework before deciding to render the default page.

Ideally, a "strict" mode would return only for the root URL (whatever it may be) and all other URLs would be at the server-side leisure for what to return.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Request: Configurable folders to serve the client from" (#1567)

Issues.Title: Update README.md
Issues.Body: Add links to the docs.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Update README.md" (#1565)

Issues.Title: "Fixed" mode and E2E tests for <CascadingValue>
Issues.Body:
This is a follow-up to #1545.

It's a perf optimization that allows the framework to skip the subscription tracking and parameter snapshotting that it normally has to do when cascading parameters might change value. The intended use case is for things like "form context" or anywhere you do:

    <CascadingValue Value=this>...</CascadingValue>

... because if the `Value` instance is constant for the lifetime of the `<CascadingValue>`, we can make this really cheap.

If developers fail to apply this optimization when they could, nothing bad happens. We only expect this optimization to be used by our framework components and more advanced component authors who have proactively read docs about this.

**Also, E2E tests**

It was convenient to chain the E2E tests for cascading parameter/value in general to this PR. As usual, the E2E tests are not meant to cover every possible combination of use cases and error scenarios (that's in the unit tests); the E2E tests are a representative sample of high-level common scenarios.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR ""Fixed" mode and E2E tests for <CascadingValue>" (#1566)

Issues.Title: Add Cascading flag to Parameter
Issues.Body:
... so that components that pass through an arbitrary set of parameters can choose to filter out cascading ones if they want.

This is a follow-up to #1545.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Add Cascading flag to Parameter" (#1564)

Issues.Title: Add ability to override blazor config
Issues.Body:
Adds the ability within the BlazorOptions to set a custom BlazorConfig, if none is provided, the standard .blazor.config file is loaded.

Quite useful when using customised development environments. I remotely start and debug the blazor server straight from visual studio on a different machine using ssh what means the paths need to be set at runtime instead of being read from the config file.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Add ability to override blazor config" (#1560)

Issues.Title: Template context not working
Issues.Body:
Hello there, I'm trying to use the new Template Components as seen in here https://blazor.net/docs/components/index.html#templated-components. I used the Forecast example created when you creates a new solution with Blazor (default one that runs the WebAssembly). So I created a file in Shared folder named TemplateTable.cshtml, as follows: ``` @typeparam TItem
@TableHeader @foreach (var item in Items) { @RowTemplate(item) } @TableFooter
@functions { [Parameter] RenderFragment TableHeader { get; set; } [Parameter] RenderFragment RowTemplate { get; set; } [Parameter] RenderFragment TableFooter { get; set; } [Parameter] IReadOnlyList Items { get; set; } } ``` In the FetchData.cshtml that was generated by the example, I added: ``` Date Temp. (C) Temp. (F) Summary @context.Date.ToShortDateString() @context.TemperatureC @context.TemperatureF @context.Summary ``` But I'm getting compiling errors as follow: ``` Error CS0103 The name 'context' does not exist in the current context WebApplication1 C:\git\github\WebApplication1\WebApplication1\Pages\FetchData.cshtml 44 Active Error CS0103 The name 'context' does not exist in the current context WebApplication1 C:\git\github\WebApplication1\WebApplication1\Pages\FetchData.cshtml 45 Active Error CS0103 The name 'context' does not exist in the current context WebApplication1 C:\git\github\WebApplication1\WebApplication1\Pages\FetchData.cshtml 46 Active Error CS0103 The name 'context' does not exist in the current context WebApplication1 C:\git\github\WebApplication1\WebApplication1\Pages\FetchData.cshtml 47 Active ``` I checked everything that seems possible to be happen: Visual Studio 2017 version: 15.8.7 ASP.NET Core Blazor Language Services: 15.7.20181002.2 My csproj versions: ``` netstandard2.0 dotnet blazor serve 7.3 ``` The global.json for the project: ``` { "sdk": { "version": "2.1.402" } } ``` I also tried the other variations of the context, like `` and `` Am I missing anything else? Or is this a bug indeed?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Template context not working" (#1559)

Issues.Title: BindMethods.cs does not parse a number when using 'input type="number"'
Issues.Body:
Error occurs when using **Blazor Server Side**.
Using the `type="number"` parameter I cannot use `double / float / decimal` in `bind`.

**TestPage.cshtml**
```
@page "/testpage"

@functions {
    protected double sum { get; set; }
}

<input type="number" bind="@sum" />
```

When I enter field `4.1` or `4,1`, I get an error.
```
Uncaught (in promise) Error: System.FormatException: Input string was not in a correct format.
   at Microsoft.JSInterop.DotNetDispatcher.InvokeSynchronously(String assemblyName, String methodIdentifier, Object targetInstance, String argsJson)
   at Microsoft.JSInterop.DotNetDispatcher.BeginInvoke(String callId, String assemblyName, String methodIdentifier, Int64 dotNetObjectId, String argsJson)

   at Microsoft.JSInterop.DotNetDispatcher.InvokeSynchronously(String assemblyName, String methodIdentifier, Object targetInstance, String argsJson)
   at Microsoft.JSInterop.DotNetDispatcher.BeginInvoke(String callId, String assemblyName, String methodIdentifier, Int64 dotNetObjectId, String argsJson)
    at endInvokeDotNetFromJS (http://localhost:57231/_framework/blazor.server.js:23:48593)
    at http://localhost:57231/_framework/blazor.server.js:23:48162
    at new Promise (<anonymous>)
    at e.beginInvokeJSFromDotNet (http://localhost:57231/_framework/blazor.server.js:23:48131)
    at http://localhost:57231/_framework/blazor.server.js:16:11652
    at Array.forEach (<anonymous>)
    at e.invokeClientMethod (http://localhost:57231/_framework/blazor.server.js:16:11623)
    at e.processIncomingData (http://localhost:57231/_framework/blazor.server.js:16:10229)
    at e.connection.onreceive (http://localhost:57231/_framework/blazor.server.js:16:7298)
    at WebSocket.i.onmessage (http://localhost:57231/_framework/blazor.server.js:16:20346)
endInvokeDotNetFromJS @ blazor.server.js:23
(anonymous) @ blazor.server.js:23
beginInvokeJSFromDotNet @ blazor.server.js:23
(anonymous) @ blazor.server.js:16
e.invokeClientMethod @ blazor.server.js:16
e.processIncomingData @ blazor.server.js:16
connection.onreceive @ blazor.server.js:16
i.onmessage @ blazor.server.js:16
```

An error occurs in this method.
https://github.com/aspnet/Blazor/blob/10bdf5b0adc26d781cb54a5764accf11274df2e1/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor/Components/BindMethods.cs#L117

```cs
public static Action<UIEventArgs> SetValueHandler(Action<double> setter, double existingValue)
{
   return _ =>
      {
         var val = (string)((UIChangeEventArgs)_).Value;  // res: 4.1  <= The value is always with a dot.
         var sum = double.Parse(val);                     // System.FormatException
         setter(sum);                                     // Not called
      };
}
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "BindMethods.cs does not parse a number when using 'input type="number"'" (#1556)

Issues.Title: Failed in resolving dependencies After adding msgpack-cli
Issues.Body:
msgpack-cli currently support mono build. https://github.com/msgpack/msgpack-cli
But I got errors MSB3037 while making build.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40863525/46847071-b23be800-ce0c-11e8-88cf-b6eeda031b49.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Failed in resolving dependencies After adding msgpack-cli" (#1553)

Issues.Title: Cannot resolve @typeparam
Issues.Body:
I have Blazor 0.6.0 installed, using the VS template.  .NET Core SDK 2.1.402.  I see this, both with ReSharper enabled and disabled.  

The app appears to still compile and run correctly, so perhaps this is an issue with Visual Studio?  I have VS 2017 15.8.6.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14915247/46832614-1fe40780-cd6c-11e8-9cc5-c7ee4a70d848.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Cannot resolve @typeparam" (#1552)

Issues.Title: Suggestion: Adding Directive
Issues.Body:
I'd love to see the ability of supporting also directives, same principle as Angular.

<input MyDirective />

Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Suggestion: Adding Directive" (#1551)
